title.narrative: Yes I do Indonesia

description.narrative: Activities include: development/adaptation information package on the specific Yes I Do objectives; organizing awareness sessions on social and gender norms, child rights and SRHR in the communities; strengthening of CSOs including Child Protection Committees on their institutional capacities and knowledge of child protection and SHRH laws and policies.

Deep-rooted norms and expectations of girls and boys makes families and communities feel the need to control the sexuality of girls by marrying them off. Gender inequality is putting girls in a subordinate position with regard to boys and men in (sexual) relationships. For example, girls cannot refuse to have unprotected sex and this is resulting in a high level of teenage pregnancies. Girls and boys lack a voice, as well as the support to break through these norms and practices. The means and structures available for adolescents to organise themselves and claim their rights are limited and they have little access to adolescent-friendly and good quality SRHR information and services. There are close links between EM and teenage pregnancies and girls’ lack of education. Indeed, girls’ access to education is very restricted, which makes it difficult for them to find jobs later. It also hampers their economic independence. Legislation to outlaw EM is either inadequate or is being poorly implemented.

EM and teenage pregnancies mutually reinforce one another. Social and gender norms perpetuating EM are deeply embedded in communities and this situation can only be changed if community leaders and most of the people, including boys and men, support the change. Key persons in the communities, including boys and men, will be turned into allies in the process of changing these norms, thereby helping to address the problem of EM and teenage pregnancies. A general lack of information about SRHR and poor quality and access to the relevant services are perpetuating the above-mentioned problems. Further, the social and gender norms denies especially to girls adequate access to quality secondary education and vocational training. Adolescent boys and girls are being informed about SRHR and given a voice to claim these rights. Girls are being given more control over their lives. This is being achieved by changing these norms and people’s behaviour, strengthening networks and structures for social mobilisation and embedding these in communities, and by involving the government and the private sector in improving SRHR and services. Improved access especially for girls to secondary education and vocational training will enhance their career opportunities and economic independence. All these will help to reduce EM and teenage pregnancies.
Final beneficiaries are girls between the age of 12 – 24 years, married and unmarried

SUMMARY Millions of adolescent girls all over the world are facing a limited future because of early marriage (EM) and teenage pregnancies. With this project, by changing the attitude of community members and other key persons and informing adolescent girls and boys, adolescents will be empowered to stand up for their sexual reproductive health and rights (SRHR). Through education and economic empowerment, supported by the relevant legislation and policies, the project will give adolescents alternatives beyond EM and teenage pregnancies. The project will be implemented between 2016 and 2020 by Plan International Nederland, together with partners Rutgers, Choice, KIT and the Netherlands’ Embassy in Jakarta (Indonesia). Next to Indonesia, similar projects under the same framework will be carried out in Ethiopia, Kenya, Zambia, Mozambique, Malawi and Pakistan.

Sustainability will be achieved a.o. through strengthening of local CSOs including youth led in their institutional and knowledge capacities, involvement of and cooperation with key stakeholders including local government representatives, community and religious leaders and private partners. Key research gaps will be identified with the key stakeholders and direct beneficiaries and will be addressed to improve evidence based lobby and advocacy towards preventing CM and TP. Further strategies to enhance sustainability will be developed in the course of the project implementation.

title.narrative: 0154 Children, youth or adults have skills to make changes to their lives
% girls aged 15-18 currently attending secondary school (Lombok Barat) (pathway 4)

description.narrative: A community-based cluster sample survey was administered at the household level among young girls and boys aged 15-24 in two intervention areas (Sukabumi- Lombok Barat). The survey included question about child marriage- teenage pregnancy and female circumcision. We obtained a sample size of 1528 using a standard formula- taking into account possible “design effects” because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. a total of 1534 questionnaires were administered- slightly above to the planned target. No contributing partners.

comment.narrative: % girls aged 15-18 currently attending secondary school (Lombok Barat) (pathway 4)

title.narrative: 0212 Communities take charge of their own development processes
# of initiatives in the local community and local clubs/associations/schools to address FGM, TP and CM and gender inequality

comment.narrative: # of initiatives in the local community and local clubs/associations/schools to address FGM, TP and CM and gender inequality
Target for 2020 was inb total 6 initiatives a.o. by KPADs.

In totoal in 2020, 8 initiatives were reached a.o. Circular Government Letter from Head of Lembar Selatan Village: This circular letter socialized the changes of national law regarding the minimum age of marriage and establishment of district law regarding prevention of child marriage. 3. Village government and community in two intervention villages agreed to allocate some village funds for the FAD (Forum Anak Desa - Village Children Forum) to mobilise their peers towards empowering activities
target number of initiatives for the full calender year

Initiatives include campaigns to address CM and TP initiated by local groups of serial discussion member, circulation of letter by village head to socialize the new minimum age of marriage, allocated funds from village government for KPADs, allocated funds from education district department for child-friendly school development, allocated resources from schools to implement business classes, drafting village law on child protection, and legal support from the child protection district department regarding facilitators to develop and strengthen KPADs. These initiatives were the result of increasing the functionality of KPADs and other networks of change agents (child-friendly school teams, CLCs). Facilitated by the implementing partners, they coordinated more effectively with other elements of stakeholders to advocate the issues towards related governments (village government, departments in the district government). Other than that, their initiative to mainstream the issues in village events also increased.

Two new KPADs (one in Lombok and one in Sukabumi) succeeded in advocating for village funds in 2020. Two KPADs and FADs in Rembang succeeded in advocating for Village Children Forum’s access to village funds.

title.narrative: 0611 Policies and legislations are being aligned with the with rights of children and youth and gender equality

comment.narrative: 0611.3 Number of proposed policies and laws that are in line with the rights of children and youth and/or gender equality debated political institutions

1. Circular Government Letter from the Head of Lembar Selatan Village regarding prevention of child marriage 2. Regent Regulations of West Lombok regarding Education Department Unit to support implementation of child friendly school. 3. District Regulation of West Lombok regarding the child friendly district development. 4. Decree of West Lombok District Regeant that stated full support to 12 child friendly village in the district. Two of our intervened villages are included.
Target for 2020

For 2019, national and local laws and policies consist of decree from the education district department and religion district department of Sukabumi regarding the development of child-friendly school in regular and religious schools; decree from the head of schools and CLCs regarding the development of child-friendly school working team, implementation of child-friendly school and child protection; policies to allocate funds for the development of child-friendly schools from the education district department of West Lombok, West Lombok District Law in addressing child marriage, decree from the head of village regarding CM prevention and socializing the new marriage law, and decree from the child protection district department of West Lombok regarding the KPAD development and strengthening facilitators.

title.narrative: 1000 Vocational, business and life skills training for children, youth or adults
Number of boys who completed vocational skills trainings (pathway 4)

comment.narrative: Number of boys who completed vocational skills trainings (pathway 4)
target set for 2020 as for new/additional students taking part in the business class.
As schools were closed part of the time, target was not met. In the whole year 2020. 69 boys took part in the business classes (of which 15 newly joined in 2020).

Business classes at the village/community level in 2020 focus to strengthen the previous years business groups and ensure business class sustainability in villages and schools. However, there is an increasing enthusiasm from the intervened schools to implement business class as well. In 2020, there are six intervened schools that implement business class as regular extracurricular activity and four schools that integrate business class materials to art and craft lessons. Unfortunately the business class activities were all freezed due to COVID-19 pandemic. Virtual classes through Whatsapp group were tried to be implemented by implementing partners. However, some villages have more difficult access to internet connectivity thus the business classes beneficiaires there couldn’t participate actively in the virtual meetings.
Total number of boys 10-24 in 2019 who learnt vocational, business and financial skills
number of boys who participated in weekend business classes (10-18) and in economic empowerment trainings (18-24)
number of boys who participate in weekend business classes learning and applying vocational and entrepeneurial (financial) skills
number of boys who participated in weekend business classes

As schools were closed part of the time, target was not met. In the whole year 2020, 260 girls took part in the business classes (of which 61 newly joined in 2020).

Business classes at the village/community level in 2020 focus to strengthen the previous years business groups and ensure business class sustainability in villages and schools. However, there is an increasing enthusiasm from the intervened schools to implement business class as well. In 2020, there are six intervened schools that implement business class as regular extracurricular activity and four schools that integrate business class materials to art and craft lessons. Unfortunately the business class activities were all freezed due to COVID-19 pandemic. Virtual classes through Whatsapp group were tried to be implemented by implementing partners. However, some villages have more difficult access to internet connectivity thus the business classes beneficiaires there couldn’t participate actively in the virtual meetings.

title.narrative: 0511 Service providers respond to the needs and rights of children and youth
Number of schools where a Child Protection Policy is in place (pathway 4)

comment.narrative: Number of schools where a Child Protection Policy is in place (pathway 4)

9 in Sukabumi, 7 in Rembang, and 7 in West Lombok Based on newly developed standards of Child-Friendly School (1. Integrity Pact, 2. Head Master’s Decree for CFS Work Team, 3. Child-friendly School Rules/Code of Conduct, 4. Availability of Trained Teachers (regarding Child Rights & Protection, and Reproductive Health) 5. Referral mechanism in responding to cases of violence, 6. Recording of reported cases of violence, including child marriage and teenage pregnancy, and 7. Implementation of Reproductive Health Education) there are 12 schools (5 Sukabumi, 3 Rembang, and 4 Lombok) that have met these 7 minimum standards:
These schools have become child friendly schools already before 2020 and will be continuing to improve on this.

Apart from the 23 schools that continuously implement activities on Safe Schools, Child-friendly school development within the three district is continuously followed up with the related stakeholders, mainly the education department of district government. Support from the district government plays an important role to ensure the sustainability of current CFS initiatives and enforce the scaling up of it. As part of sustainability, the process of developing CFS in the three districts was documented into a practical module that is guiding the district government and other schools to scale up the initiative. Currently, all intervened junior high schools have completed the minimum indicator of CFS agreed together with the district government. In realizing this, several seminar and workshops have been held in the 3 intervention districts. The guideline of CFS implementation in the 3 districts have been developed and socialized. Currently, there are eight other schools (five in West Lombok, three in Sukabumi) that have initiated the implementation of CFS model and approach. In West Lombok, the educational district department decided to replicate the CFS model to other 51 schools for 2021.

Two junior high schools have completed partially the minimum requirements of child friendly school that have been agreed upon by schools and district education department. By early of 2020, those two junior high schools have completed all requirements. Only two CLCs and one senior high school that have not completed the minimum requirement. The following up action regarding this matter will be continue in the second semester of 2020.

schools apply the minimum standards of Child-Friendly Schools Based on newly developed standards of Child-Friendly School (1. Integrity Pact, 2. Head Master’s Decree for CFS Work Team, 3. Child-friendly School Rules/Code of Conduct, 4. Availability of Trained Teachers (regarding Child Rights & Protection, and Reproductive Health) 5. Referral mechanism in responding to cases of violence, 6. Recording of reported cases of violence, including child marriage and teenage pregnancy, and 7. Implementation of Reproductive Health Education) there are 12 schools (5 Sukabumi, 3 Rembang, and 4 Lombok) that have met these 7 minimum standards:

title.narrative: 3000 Capacity training for CSOs
Number of CSO officials reached with capacity training

comment.narrative: Number of CSO officials reached with capacity training

Targeted are all 120 KPAD members to receive multiple trainings on various subjects (child protection, child rights, gender, how to report cases etc.). Trainings are based on a manual by Plan Indonesia, leading to functional KPADs.
50 KPAD members were trained of which 23 were new members
target for 2020

Additional/new KPAD (community child protection mechanism) members trained. Apart from this, the other KPAD members (in total 120-plus) benefited from the continuous organisational capacity strenghtening of their KPADs by Plan and partners.
target for 2020
Members of child protection committees (KPADs)
total number of KPAD members who participated in training
additional two members to the 247 earlier in 2019, in total 249
period CY17

title.narrative: Number of CSOs reached with capacity training

description.narrative: This refers to community-based child protection mechanisms (KPAD)

comment.narrative: 12 KPADs (total number of KPADs as part of YIDA) were planned to be further capacitated in 2018.
Only 3 out of 12 established KPADs were capacitated in 2018, all in Rembang, of which one was a new KPAD as YIDA had to move to a new village in 2018.
4 KPADs (child protection committees) and their members (further) strenghtened and trained

Technical assistance was given in 2020 with focus on gender transformative approach, children and youth meaningful participation, and advocacy skills, including monitoring and evaluation. Newly joint KPAD members participated in KPAD technical assistance sessions ; out of 57 new KPAD members whose capacity strengthened in 2020, 33 are children and youth. Other than face-to-face technical assistance Plan Indonesia also held online technical assistance for KPAD Two online meetings have been conducted with topics surrounding child protection, violence against children, and education in COVID-19 settings. Previously, several villages in Sukabumi district were targeted as PATBM (government programme of CBCPM) intervention villages by the district government. Due to miscommunication between parties, there were new bodies that planned to be developed in the village which has the same function as KPAD. This duality might cause confusion within the community and diverted village funds. Plan and its implementing partners have successfully advocated this issue to the district and village government. This result in the union of both bodies and strengthened government support for the KPAD(s). Previously, several villages in Sukabumi district were targeted as PATBM (government programme of CBCPM) intervention villages by the district government. Due to miscommunication between parties, there were new bodies that planned to be developed in the village which has the same function as KPAD. This duality might cause confusion within the community and divert village funds. Plan and its implementing partners have successfully advocated this issue to the district and village government. This result in the union of both bodies and strengthened government support for the KPAD(s).
12 KPADs (community based child protection committees) will receive trainings and organisational strenghtening
all KPADs (3 per working districts) received intensive training according to the training manual

title.narrative: 6200 Influencing policy makers
Number of advocacy initiatives for policy makers

location.ref: Sukabumi, Rembang, West Lombok and National

comment.narrative: target for 2020

15 advocacy meetings held with various policy makers including with Ministry of Education at district level on Child Friendly Schools and with local stakeholders on child protection; in each working district one advocacy meeting was held with local leaders and district stakeholders to ensure sustainability of the program results
target for 2020

Early in 2020, several advocacy meetings were held with goverment and regional leaders on the enhancement of community-based child protection, Child Friendly Schools and the weekend business classess concept as initiated by Plan as part of Yes I Do. In February 2020, three major advocacy events were held (one in each working district() where government and other stakeholders committed to take forward the results and learnings as achieved by YIDA. Follow-up meetings on this were held with the district stakeholders later in the year. Also further L&A was done with Education department and child-friendly intervention schools in two districts (Sukabumi and West Lombok) which initiated a child friendly school forum. The forum will hold regular offline meetings and online coordination in regards to child-friendly school implementation and development. Education department and business class in-school facilitators in West Lombok initiated a business class facilitator forum. The forum will hold regular offline meetings and online coordination in regards to business class implementation and development in schools. Also, several seminar and workshops have been held in 3 intervention districts. Plan Indonesia developed a guideline on Child Friendly School implementation which was socialized n the three working districts . Currently, there are eight non-intervention schools (five in West Lombok, three in Sukabumi) that have initiated the implementation of CFS model and approach. In West Lombok, the educational district department decided to replicate the CFS model to other 51 schools for 2021.

location.ref: Sukabumi, Rembang, West Lombok and national
